Sustainable WASH access: validating and testing relevant WETwin Research Project tools: the geo localisation of the pollution areas in Konna municipality – as part of the visualising means for people to be able to make water management related decisions - has been done and these data are currently being used to develop a GIS map with collected data. Further discussion and information provision with the municipality took place in the frame of IWRM in their communal plan.
2. Development and organisation of training workshop at national level for all WASH Alliance partners with focus on how to take into account the ecological context of WASH interventions. Finalised.
3. Policy brief development on IWRM and WASH for policy makers and key actors: A ToR for this activity has been developed and a consultant selection process has started.
4. Representation and facilitation of linkage with relevant partners and stakeholders (WETwin a.o.)

Financial sustainability : Wetlands International has a subcontractor position in the WASH Alliance Programme focusing on Environmental (“E”) sustainability activities. From the start it is envisioned that WI engagement in the Mali Country Programme would play an important role in building up the portfolio within the Alliance regarding the practical ways of how ecological sustainability can be made part of WASH delivery. This experience is important for linking and learning at different levels of the Alliance and for South-South exchange.

In the Mali Country Programme Wetlands International Mali plays an important role in building up the portfolio within the Alliance regarding the practical ways of how ecological sustainability can be made part of WASH delivery. This experience is important for linking and learning at different levels of the Alliance and for South-South exchange.

The geo localisation of the pollution areas in Konna municipality – as part of the visualising means for people to be able to make water management related decisions - has been done and these data are currently being used to develop a GIS map with collected data.
The follow-up of the E-sustainability workshop for the DWA Mali partners workshop has been organised in such a way that from this group work results a Malian WASH partners’ supported technical action plan would be developed which will be elaborated to an operational plan including budget allocation starting 2012 and covering the period 2012-2015.

Through WI Mali, the outcomes of the WETwin research programme focused on water quality and water management in the IND are brought in, benefiting the WASH Programme. Further WI Mali plays a direct E-actor and facilitation role in Alliance Programme, bringing particular knowledge and experience for this to the table.
Training and capacity building on ecological sustainability of WASHprojects

WASH activities in all intervention areas in general, and of the in Inner Niger Delta in particular, are vulnerable and depend deeply on the upstream water management regime. In most cases, ecosystems services are the main factor to which communities rely on in terms of their livelihood. It is not rare to see that population give priority to livelihood more than sanitation infrastructure.
